avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed especially above approximately 2300 m. They are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack can be released even by individual winter sport participants on wind-loaded slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

On wind-loaded slopes dry loose snow avalanches are possible above approximately 2300 m, in particular in the vicinity of peaks, especially in case of releases originating from very steep starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. Small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2300 m, especially on very steep sunny slopes.
In addition in areas not adjacent to ridgelines, individual medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The wind slabs are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain. The near-surface layers of the snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.

snowpackStructure.comment:
In some localities 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2200 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen. Until Friday the wind will be strong over a wide area.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Artificially triggered avalanches and stability tests confirm the complex avalanche situation in particular in the regions exposed to substantial precipitation.

The weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers on Wednesday in particular on very steep sunny slopes, in particular below approximately 2300 m.

tendency.comment: The danger will persist. The extensive wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible.

avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind from northwesterly directions, mostly shallow wind slabs formed. They are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
In particular on wind-loaded slopes mostly small dry loose snow avalanches are possible above approximately 2300 m, in particular in the vicinity of peaks.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2300 m, especially on very steep sunny slopes.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.

snowpackStructure.comment:
In some localities 0 to 10 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2200 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen. Until Friday the wind will be strong over a wide area. As a consequence of a strong to storm force northwesterly wind, rather small wind slabs formed during the night. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers on Wednesday in particular on very steep sunny slopes, in particular below approximately 2300 m.
The new snow of last week has bonded well with the old snowpack in all aspects.
The upper section of the snowpack is not distinctly layered.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m less snow than usual is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
